detail.content: Steve Stoute: Tisch School of the Arts at NYU                           Skip to content        Recorded Music Program Courses Internships News & Events Facilities Alumni Faculty Directory Recorded Music FAQs For High School Students Facebook Twitter YouTube Summer In Recorded Music Academic Advisement Resources 194 Recordings  home > Recorded Music          Recorded Music   Steve Stoute Instructor, Recorded Music  Biography                                     Steve Stoute is the founder and chief executive officer of leading brand  marketing firm Translation. His track record as a consumer brand marketer for  Fortune 500 companies makes him one of today’s most influential voices in  entertainment marketing and pop culture. With a diverse client  roster that includes brands such as McDonald’s, State Farm, Target, Wm. Wrigley  Jr. Co and Lady Gaga, Mr. Stoute continues to revolutionize the way blue chip  marketers and superstar artists connect with consumers. From 1990 to 1999, Mr. Stoute was a senior executive at several leading  labels in the music industry. At Interscope Geffen A&M Records, he served  as president of the Urban Music division and executive vice president. Prior to  joining Interscope, he was president of Urban Music for Sony Music  Entertainment. Mr. Stoute was also manager to rapper Nas and singer Mary J.  Blige. Outside of his work in the advertising world, Mr. Stoute is co-founder of the  Foundation for the Advancement of Women Now (FFAWN) with Mary J. Blige, whose  mission is to educate and empower women through scholarships, grants and career  development opportunities. In 2009 they opened their first facility, the Mary  J. Blige Center for Women in Yonkers, New York. Mr. Stoute is also the CEO and Managing Director of beauty  line Carol’s Daughter, a Brooklyn-based beauty and haircare line that claims  Jay-Z, Will & Jada Pinkett Smith, Thalia, Mary J. Blige, Tommy Mottola and  Jimmy Iovine as investors. In these roles, he identifies and secures new  partnerships with companies such as Disney and AVON. In September 2011, Mr. Stoute released his first book, The Tanning of America, a study on how hip hop culture has transformed a polyethnic generation, influenced the global marketplace and rewritten the rules of the new economy. Facebook     Windows Live     Yahoo                 MySpace     Email                   Bread Crumbs                Home          >           Academics          >           Courses          >           Course Detail                                        Hip-Hop Trails: Tracing and Rediscovering the Origins and Legacy of Hip-Hop Culture                                Semester and Year        FA 2013                    Course Number        CLI-UG1436                    Section        001                    Instructor        Martha Diaz                    Days                            Fri                                 Time                            3:30 PM -       6:10 PM                                Units        4.0                    Level        U                    Foundation Requirement                                                  Description       There is no doubt that Hip-Hop is ubiquitous through radio and television commercials, music videos, films, magazines, billboards, and video games. However, the Hip-Hop we see today is not the same Hip-Hop that we saw when early pioneers formed a distinct sub-culture (encompassing MCing, Beatboxing, DJing, bboying, and graffiti) to speak to the experiences of disenfranchised youth across the world. Commercialization has created two kinds of Hip-Hop: one is focused on the community and connected to a long legacy and history of Black/Caribbean experience, and a second focused on individualism and celebrating instant gratification, funded by big corporations to sell brands and consumption as a lifestyle. What determining factors caused this evolution and what does it mean? This course traces Hip-Hop’s history and its influences through participatory action research, media literacy, and service learning. Students will learn to analyze, interpret, chronicle, and sample Hip-Hop. In collaboration with The Schomburg Center’s Hip-Hop 4.0 Initiative (Education, Creativity, Community, and Legacy), and other institutions/organizations in the New York area (such as the Hip-Hop Education Center, Graffiti Hall of Fame), students will have access to Hip-Hop repositories, lectures, panel discussions, film screenings, and guest speakers. Students will also work on the first major exhibition celebrating Hip-Hop's 40th anniversary at the Schomburg Center. Books include:  Yes, Yes Ya’ll  by Jim Fricke and Charlie Ahearn,  Hip-Hop Generation  by Bakari Kitwana,  The Tanning of America  by Steve Stoute and  That’s The Joint!  by Murray Forman and Marc Anthony Neal.
